Award.AwardTitle: Facility Support: The WiscSIMS National Ion Microprobe
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports WiscSIMS as a National Facility for Stable Isotope Geochemistry. WiscSIMS includes an IMS-1280 ion microprobe that is optimized for analysis of stable isotopes (H, Li, B, C, N, O, Mg, Si, S, Cl, Ca, and Fe). WiscSIMS has developed unique capabilities for precise and accurate analysis of isotope ratios from small to ultra small spots. The ability to analyze small spots (1-10 microns) in situ from microscope mounts allows data to be put in context with imaging and other forms of analysis.

The availability of these new in situ capabilities has led to many exciting discoveries and is causing revolutionary changes in areas of geochemistry. The range and pattern of isotope variation can finally be determined from small objects that were formerly homogenized by analysis of bulk or powdered samples such as zircons, microfossils, and diagenetic cements. New and surprising information of fundamental importance has been found in many areas. For instance, high-resolution studies of continental paleoclimate had been limited to resolution at decade- to century-scale by conventional sampling techniques and yet ice-core records show that extreme shifts in climate can occur in less than 10 years. Recently, SIMS analysis of stalagmites has resolved changes in oxygen isotope ratio for one month or less, providing a record of seasonality and annual-scale climate. WiscSIMS has published proof-of-concept studies of many proxies of paleoclimate including speleothems, foraminifera, mollusks, fish otoliths, and calcretes and plans others including diatoms and biogenic phosphates.

The broader impacts of this project include new applications of stable isotope geochemistry to problems of societal concern; public education; and training in geochemistry at undergraduate to post-doc level, including under-represented groups. In the first five years of operation, over 130 scientists have worked with WiscSIMS from 60 different universities and research institutes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The WiscSIMS Lab is a National Facility for Stable Isotope Geochemistry. Funding from NSF-EAR permits guest users to work with WiscSIMS scientists and obtain unprecedented accuracy and sample sizes over one million times smaller than conventional techniques. In situ analysis correlates isotope ratios to imaging and other geochemistry. These capabilities offer transformative opportunities in a wide range of Earth Science, including paleoclimatology, paleontology, oceanography, archeology, astrobiology, sedimentology, volcanology, economic geology, igneous & metamorphic petrology, and meteoritics.

            During the previous award period, there were 47 projects, including 18 student theses, from UW-Madison and 68 from 50 external organizations. There were 102 non-UW-Madison users, including 38 students. 87 papers were published reporting WiscSIMS studies in high-impact peer-reviewed journals and 155 abstracts at national and international meetings. 75 researchers attended each of the WiscSIMS-hosted Conferences on High Resolution Proxies of Paleoclimate in 2013 and 2015.

Figures.

The WiscSIMS Laboratory, Department of Geoscience, University of Wisconsin-Madison specializes in analysis of stable isotope ratios from ultra-small samples. Applications range from Paleoclimatology and Astrobiology to Igneous rocks and Meteorites.

Biennial conferences on High Resolution Proxies of Climate Change have been hosted at WiscSIMS in 2015 and 2013. http://www.geology.wisc.edu/~wiscsims/HiRes2015/.

In the first Atom Probe Tomography of a mineral, atom-by-atom location and isotope analysis of Pb confirms the fidelity of SIMS oxygen isotopes and U-Pb ages. These results show that Earth was habitable for life over 800 million years before the oldest known fossils (Valley et al. 2014, 2015).

In situ SIMS analysis of oxygen and carbon isotope ratios in lab-cultured marine microfossils record diurnal growth variation. These results highlight potential for paleoceanographic, biomineralization, and paleoclimatic applications on microfossils (Vetter et al. 2012, 2013).

In situ analysis of stable isotope ratios reveal seasonal variations for the first time in cave dripstones from China. These results track post-glacial changes in the amount and source of summer monsoon rainfall and allow refinement of models to predict future climate change (Orland et al. 2015).

In situ SIMS analysis shows that titanites from a major shear zone in the Adirondack Mts. are zoned in oxygen isotope ratio and U-Pb age. Diffusion modeling shows that the terrane cooled quickly due to gravitational collapse of the Grenville Mtn. belt 1 billion years ago (Bonamici et al. 2013, 2015)
